qas.question: Of what were materials that left little residue thought to contain?
What type of combustible materials were considered to have little philogiston?
What distinct quality of combustion was  absent from philogiston theory?

answers.text: a substance like wood gains overall weight in burning

qas.question: What material's weight gain during rusting was an early clue that philogiston theory was wrong?
What characteristic due most items display after burning?

answers.text: appear to become lighter and seem to lose something in the process

qas.question: What was iron found to be made mostly of?

plausible_answers.text: was that metals, too, gain weight in rusting

qas.question: What was a first clue that the phlogiston theory was correct?
Who was iron thought to have a lot of?

context: Highly combustible materials that leave little residue, such as <b6_0>wood or coal<b6_0/>, were thought to be made mostly of <a0_1><a0_2><a0_3><a0_4><b5_0><b8_0>phlogiston<b8_0/><b5_0/><a0_4/><a0_3/><a0_2/><a0_1/>; whereas <a1_0><a1_1>non-combustible<a1_0/> substances that corrode<a1_1/>, such as iron, contained very little. <a2_0><a2_1><a2_2><a2_3>Air<a2_3/><a2_2/><a2_1/><a2_0/> did not play a role in <a0_0>phlogiston<a0_0/> theory, nor were any initial quantitative experiments conducted to test the idea; instead, it was based on observations of what happens when something burns, that most common objects <a4_1><a4_2><a4_3>appear to <a4_0>become <a4_4>lighter<a4_4/><a4_2/><a4_1/><a4_0/> and seem to lose something in the process<a4_3/>. The fact that <a2_4>a substance like <a1_2><a1_3>wood<a1_3/><a1_2/> gains overall weight in burning<a2_4/> was hidden by the buoyancy of the gaseous combustion products. Indeed, one of the first clues that the phlogiston theory was incorrect <b7_0>was that <a3_0><a3_1><a3_2><a3_3><a3_4>metals<a3_4/><a3_3/><a3_2/><a3_1/><a3_0/>, too, gain weight in rusting<b7_0/> (when they were supposedly losing phlogiston).
